application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: Decentralized and Adaptive Nonlinear Tracking of Large-Scale Systems via Output Feedback
div.p: Zhong-Ping Jiang

Abstract-This paper presents for the first time a solution to the problem of decentralized adaptive asymptotic tracking for a new class of large-scale systems using nonlinear output feedback. The proposed constructive approach does not require any matching conditions on the parametric uncertainties nor growth conditions of any kind on the subsystem and interacting output nonlinearities. Any decentralized system in the family may have an unknown, nonzero equilibrium point. Partially decentralized reduced-order filters are presented to recover the unmeasured states. The recursive, decentralized, output-feedback design procedure is illustrated in a practical example of two inverted pendulums on carts without velocity measurements. The effectiveness of the decentralized algorithm is supported by simulation results.
Index Terms-Adaptive, asymptotic tracking, decentralized nonlinear control, large-scale systems, output feedback.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Recent years have seen significant progress in the field of decentralized control of both linear and nonlinear large-scale systems; see, for instance, [1]- [5], [12]- [14], and [16] and references therein. Most work focus on the state-feedback case and less attention has been paid to the decentralized output-feedback problem for large-scale nonlinear systems. In this paper, we look at the decentralized adaptive tracking issue for a new class of large-scale nonlinear systems with limited output measurements. This problem is of fundamental importance from a theoretic point of view and is of great practical interest for applications arising from the power industry, chemical, and aerospace engineering applications. For such systems with many components, finding a completely centralized controller is often a technically challenging design problem, not to mention the practical implementation issue.

The purpose of this paper is to present the first solution to the problem of decentralized adaptive output-feedback asymptotic tracking for large-scale systems with significant nonlinearities and uncertainties. Among many important contributions to the topic at the early stage, we mention the pioneering paper [4] by Ioannou who introduced a systematic decentralized adaptive control design using the well-known M-matrix test. As he noticed, his approach suffers from some severe drawbacks. For example, the positive definiteness of the M-matrix in [4] is hard to verify because it involves unknown constants. In addition, the relative degree of each local subsystem of the decentralized system cannot be larger than two. Shortly after the publication of [4], Gavel and Šiljak [2] proposed an alternative adaptive high-gain approach without resorting to any M-matrix condition, but at the price of assuming the standard strict matching condition about the uncertainties. Motivated by the work [4], the restriction on the subsystem relative degree was completely removed by Ortega and Herrera [12] using Morse's dynamic certainty equivalence principle and by Wen and Soh [16] using integrator backstepping. (Notice that the approach of [12] cannot be extended to cover the adaptive tracking case.) Still, another major assumption on the type of uncertain interconnections in [4] remained unrelaxed until [13]. Shi and Singh of [13] considered a class of large-scale systems with higher-order interconnections. More precisely, the linear bounds for the unknown interactions in [4], [2], [12], and [16] were replaced by polynomial bounds. More recently, the authors of [5] further relaxed the strict matching assumption in [13] by mixing the high-gain approach of [2] with the adaptive backstepping of Krstic ´et al. [10]. Unfortunately, all results obtained in [4], [2], [13], [16], and [5] achieve only practical output tracking in the presence of parametric disturbances because of their "worst case" design nature. In this paper, by exploiting the structure of the interconnections, we will: 1) obtain the first solution to the much more challenging problem of decentralized adaptive output-feedback asymptotic tracking for large-scale systems with significant nonlinearities and 2) remove the polynomial-type growth conditions on the interconnections and output-nonlinearities in [5].

In contrast to [5], our class of large-scale systems (1) may possess an unknown, nonzero equilibrium. A new class of decentralized nonlinear systems is given for which no matching and growth conditions are assumed. Not surprisingly, the asymptotic tracking solution we obtain is partially decentralized as in linear decentralized control [3].

In the field of centralized adaptive control for SISO nonlinear systems, fundamental limitations and difficulties are well understood for adaptive output feedback design [10], [11], [6]. Our results demonstrate that much more can be done in the area of decentralized adaptive nonlinear control through the cross fertilization with modern developments in centralized adaptive and nonlinear control. Like in [11] and [9], the zero-dynamics of every individual system are assumed to be globally exponentially stable (GES) and the inverse dynamics enjoy certain bound-input bounded-state (BIBS) stability. However, when we restrict ourselves to output-feedback asymptotic stabilization, instead of asymptotic tracking, it has recently been shown in [7] that these severe GES and BIBS assumptions can be relaxed to a weaker input-to-state stability (ISS) property [15]. In other words, for either asymptotic stabilization or practical tracking, the decentralized methodology of [7] is applicable to a broader class of large-scale nonlinear systems than (1) in Section II.

This paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the class of decentralized systems in special output-feedback form and formulates the control objective. Section III develops a novel constructive decentralized output-feedback tracking scheme and states the main theorem. In Section IV, the benchmark example of double inverted pendulums on carts is used to illustrate the decentralized methodology. From this example, one sees that the proposed tracking scheme is quite flexible in that the nonlinearities in the decentralized system in question may depend on both the output and some unmeasured states. Our concluding remarks are contained in Section V.

div.head: II. CLASS OF SYSTEMS AND PROBLEM STATEMENT
div.p: The purpose of this paper is to address the decentralized adaptive output-feedback tracking for a class of linearly parametrized largescale nonlinear systems, whose ith-subsystem
div.formula: y i = x i1(1)
div.p: where xi 2 n , ui 2 , and yi 2 are the state, input, and output of the ith local subsystem, respectively, a i 2 n and b i = (b im ; 111 ; b i0 ) T 2 m +1 are unknown constant vectors, f i , F i , and G il are known smooth functions. In (1), ni = nx 0 mi is known as the relative degree for the ith local subsystem. From (1), one sees that the ith and lth subsystems interact via their outputs through linearly parametrized nonlinear functions G il (y l )a l and G li (yi)ai, i 6 = l. It should be pointed out that the centralized part of (1) (i.e., the interconnecting terms disappear) has been widely studied in centralized adaptive output feedback control (see, e.g., [10], [11, Part I] and references therein). The following assumptions, which are required in [9] and [11], will be used to restrict our new class of decentralized output feedback systems (1). Recall that the reference signals fyir(t)g N i=1 satisfy the following standard assumption.

(A3) For every 1 i N , the signal y ir (t) and its first n i derivatives fy (j) ir (t)g n j=1 are piecewise continuous and bounded. Our control problem is formulated as follows. To the best of our knowledge, this problem has not been addressed in the setting of decentralized nonlinear output-feedback control.

div.head: Problem of Decentralized Adaptive Output Feedback Asymptotic
div.p: Tracking: Given a set of reference signals fy ir g N i=1 satisfying Assumption (A3), find a time-varying, decentralized output-feedback control law of the form
div.formula: _ i = i (t; i ; y i ); u i = i (t; i ; y i )(2)
div.p: such that, while maintaining the boundedness of all closed-loop states, the following asymptotic tracking property is achieved
div.formula: lim t!1 N i=1
div.p: jy i (t) 0 y ir (t)j = 0:

Remark 1: It was shown in [7] that the problem of practical, or asymptotic, output regulation (i.e., y r (t) = 0 8 t 0) can be solved for a wider class of large-scale systems. Clearly, it is straightforward to extend the results of [7] to the practical output tracking problem.

(By "practical," we mean that the tracking error y e (t) = y(t) 0 y r (t) can be made small enough for sufficiently large t.) By restricting to a narrower class of large-scale systems with linearly parametrized interconnections, we complement the results of [7] with a first solution to the problem of decentralized asymptotic tracking using output feedback.

div.head: C. Main Result
div.p: We are now ready to state our main theorem on decentralized asymptotic output tracking, whose proof is outlined in the Appendix.

Theorem 1: Under Assumptions (A1)-(A3), the problem of decentralized adaptive output feedback asymptotic tracking is solvable for large-scale nonlinear systems (1). More precisely, the solutions of the closed-loop systems (1), ( 5)-( 7), (22), and ( 29)-(31) are bounded. Moreover, property (3) holds.

Remark 3: In the case of decentralized set-point regulation, i.e., when yr(t) = y ? for a set-point y ? in N , the above partially de- centralized adaptive scheme can be modified to yield a totally decentralized dynamic output feedback regulator. Indeed, for each ith subsystem, it suffices to consider the unknown, constant interconnections N l=1;l6 =i G il (y ? l )a i as another vector of unknown constant parameters. With this in mind, the N l=1;l6 =i G il (y lr ) can be taken off from (7), leading to totally decentralized

div.head: IV. AN ILLUSTRATIVE EXAMPLE
div.p: In this section, we illustrate the proposed decentralized output-feedback methodology by means of a practical example of inverted double pendulums on carts. For this decentralized benchmark example, a solution was given in [13] to the problem of decentralized full-state feedback control. Decentralized adaptive state-feedback controllers were derived in [13] to achieve the global ultimate boundedness for all states. Apart from this state-feedback solution, we are not aware of any existing decentralized output-feedback algorithm which solves the adaptive tracking problem. Here, when the angles are taken as the output, the decentralized system contains nonlinear terms that depend quadratically on the unmeasured states _ 1 and _ 2 , i.e., the angular velocities.
We show how our decentralized method can be modified to accommodate this hard technical issue.

Example 1 (Inverted Double Pendulums on Carts [13]): Consider a decentralized system which is composed of two inverted pendulums on carts, connected via a moving spring. The motion of the dynamics is described by 1 = g cl 0 ka(t)(a(t) 0 cl) cml 2 1 0 1 ( 1 ) _ (s 1 (t) 0 s 2 (t))
+ ka(t)(a(t) 0 cl) cml 2 1

where u 1 and u 2 are the control torques applied to the pivot point of each pendulum, = m=M , i(i) = sin i, l is the length of the pendulum, k and g are spring and gravity constants. We assume that > 0 is exactly known and the angles 1, 2 are the only measured states. It is further assumed that c, l, and k are unknown constants. Unlike in [13] where s 1 (t) and s 2 (t) are assumed to be sinusoidal, we can handle general time-varying and bounded horizontal displacements s1(t) and s 2 (t), which are unknown, for the practical tracking problem [7].
The system (36), (37) is not in the form (1), mainly because the vector fields depend nonlinearly on the unmeasured states _ 1 and _ 2.
Inspired by our recent work [8], nonlinear transformations are needed to bring the system (36), (37) into a decentralized system that depends affinely on the unmeasured states.

Nonlinear Transformations: For each i = 1; 2, define x i1 = i , y i = x i1 , and x i2 = e 0 cos _ i . For the asymptotic tracking problem, it is further assumed that a(t) = a ? is constant (i.e., the spring is fixed on the pendulums) and s 2 (t) 0 s 1 (t) = L, L the (known) natural length of the spring. Under this assumption, the dynamic equations of the pendulums are transformed into Fi(yi) = yi; (01) i01 L 0 yi G il (y l ) = (0; y l ) for i 6 = l:
Notice that all nonlinearities in the x 1 and x 2 subsystems now depend only on the outputs y1 = 1 and y2 = 2.

Filter Design: Although the interconnected system (38), (39) is not really in the form of (1), a simple adaptation of the decentralized filter design in Section III-A results in reduced-order input and output filters for the current system (38), (39). Indeed, we have _ vi0 = 0Lie cos y vi0 + e 0cos y ui _ i = 0L i e cos y i 0 L 2 i e cos y y i _ 4i = 0Lie cos y 4i + e 0cos y (Fi(yi) + G il (y lr )); l 6 = i: On the other hand, the xi1-system (38) can be rewritten as _ y i = b 0 e cos y v i0 + e cos y ( i + L i y i ) + e cos y i + e cos y 4ia:

(42) Therefore, for the decentralized asymptotic tracking problem, we obtain the interconnected system (41), (42), and (40) with partial-state measurements (yi; vi0). For any bounded reference signal yir(t) whose derivative _ y ir (t) is piecewise continuous and bounded, a direct application of the tracking algorithm in Section III-B yields a desired decentralized adaptive output-feedback asymptotic tracker. 1 In Figs. 1 and2, we observe that the angles 1 and 2 asymptotically track the 1 An explicit expression is available upon request. sinusoidal function sin t, under mild decentralized adaptive control efforts.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: A new class of linearly parametrized large-scale nonlinear systems in special output-feedback normal form has been identified in this paper. A partially decentralized solution has been proposed for the first time for the problem of decentralized adaptive nonlinear

div.p: output-feedback tracking, in the absence of matching assumptions on the parametric uncertainties and growth conditions on the output nonlinearities. The proposed controllers are totally decentralized for the adaptive set-point regulation problem (Remark 3). It should be mentioned that the past literature in decentralized nonlinear output-feedback control has only addressed the much less challenging problem of practical output tracking. Our control laws are developed on the basis of an effective constructive design scheme and are illustrated in a practical example of inverted double pendulums on carts without velocity measurements.

div.head: APPENDIX PROOF OF THEOREM 1
div.p: By means of (A3) and the smoothness assumption on the system vector field, every closed-loop solution exists and is unique for the same initial condition. Suppose that the solution is defined on [0; t 1 ). We wish to prove that t 1 = 1 and all the solutions are bounded. Since the second point implies the first point, we focus on the proof of the boundedness property.

From (35) and the fact that V N is radially unbounded with respect to f(i;wi; i; pi; pi0)g N i=1 , it follows that VN is bounded and, therefore, the signals (i(t);wi(t); i(t); pi(t); pi0(t)) are bounded on [0; t1) for all 1 i N . This, in turn, implies that i (t) and 4 i (t) are bounded on [0; t 1 ) because of the equality y i (t) = w i1 (t). Thus, by definition of wi in ( 26), for all 1 j ni 0 1, vim j (t) are bounded on [0; t 1 ). It remains to prove the boundedness of v im j (t) (n i j n x 0 1), x(t) and u(t). As in [10], this will be done after proving the boundedness of vi0(t) as defined in ( 5). Since we use reduced-order input and output filters in our decentralized framework, instead of full-order filters in [10], we produce a brief proof for the boundedness of v i0 (t).

To achieve this end, we need to show that every component vi0j (t) of every v i0 (t) is a bounded output of a stable linear plant excited by a bounded input. Indeed, from (5), for every 1 j n x 0 1, we have (45) Therefore, every v i0j (t) is bounded. As a consequence, t 1 = 1 and all solutions are bounded and uniformly continuous on [0; 1). From (35), every wi1(t) = yi(t) 0 yir(t) is square integrable. By applying Barbȃlat's lemma [10], the convergence (3) of y i (t) 0 y ir (t) follows readily. This completes the Proof of Theorem 1.
